description.header: 기계와의 경쟁을 준비할 한국인을 위한 오픈 컴퓨터
description.text:
• $100 달러 소프트웨어 교육 컴퓨터
  • 오픈 소스 하드웨어, 소프트웨어, 콘텐츠, 3D 설계 콘텐츠
  • 컴퓨팅 사고, 수학적 사고, 통계적 사고
I made these for a fellow airplane nut's birthday party.  I made all of these from pictures I found online and this was my first use of Inkscape.  Fantastic program!

I was amazed how easy it could be to make a cookie cutter out of any old image. 1) Find an image (preferably with most of the contrast between the object and its background: silhouettes are ideal). 2) Import it to Inkscape and click Path -> Trace Bitmap. The defaults worked great for me, but it can help to adjust the threshold on the brightness cutoff. 3) Once you click OK, a spline version of the image will be layered on top of it. I move this over so I can adjust it separately. Now you can go and tweak the splines as necessary to fix anything that won't work nicely as a cookie cutter. 4) Now I basically follow the DXF export instructions from: http://repraprip.blogspot.com/2011/05/inkscape-to-openscad-dxf-tutorial.html. The summary is Object to Path, add some more points to the splines, then convert them all to straight edges and save as DXF. 5) Open cutter.scad and tweak the base module until the DXF is sized and oriented properly (the build platform is also displayed when compiled). Export, print, and eat entertaining cookies.

comments.text: To learn how to make your own custom cookie cutter see: http://3dprintingninja.blogspot.com/2014/12/how-to-make-3d-model-from-image.html

author: alexgibson

description.text: This is a 185 size miniquad that i designed for 4 inch propellers. There are 6 standoffs and integrated mounting holes for a 36x36mm flight controller (naze, cc3d). The slots in the arms are made for mounting 1806 size motors with M2 screws. There are little slots in the arms to hold a ziptie for escs mounted on the arms. I designed it to be as strong as possible while having some cutouts in the main body of the frame and arms to reduce excessive material. The smaller slot in the main body is perfect for mounting the HS1177 camera bracket with an M3 screw and a locknut.I printed my frame and the UBQ 180 to compare the relative strengths and my frame is a bit stiffer.  I used ABS and the same infill settings. I am not positively sure if this translates to better durability in the field but I would assume so. I recommend printing in PET because the frame broke in ABS in a medium/hard crash. Have fun! Please leave comments if you think my frame can be improved in any way!

title: Replicator 1 centrifugal cooling fan and fan guard

description.text:
This is a Replicator 1 combined mount for a 50mm x 15mm 24V centrifugal cooling fan and protective covers for the existing extruder cooling fans. It's made a big difference to my PLA printing and the centrifugal fans seem to produce a stronger airflow than the usual rotatory ones. You need to cut a 45 deg slice off the centrifugal blower fan (50mm x 15mm 24V; I used this one www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00TGSJUXK ) and superglue it on to the cover (there are flats for this). The nozzles need to be glued in place on the other side. You'll also need to wire the 24V fan into the Replicator control board.
The cover is mounted on the existing Replicator 1 mounting holes using two 60mm M3 bolts; and I put two washers on the thread side of each bolt to give clearance between the cover and the Replicator 1 extruder fans.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes: You can probably print without support, but it might need a bit of smoothing with a file to get a good fit on the Replicator 1 extruder carriage.

The design "process" involved fiddling with the nozzle shape (inside & out) to try and get the air-flow in the right direction, while not hitting the hot nozzles or printed parts. I've included the SolidWorks file for the single piece - it was sliced into two STLs for easier printing and to allow easier replacement of the nozzles.

The left wheel of my BobSweep PetHair broke, and to fix I had to buy a full replacement part, which included not only the plastic wheel, but everything else, including a new motor, the metal weight inside the whell, etc. (http://owners.bobsweep.com/collections/parts-pethair/products/left-wheel) So, to avoid throwing the whole part in the garbage just because the plastic wheel broke, I thought it was a good idea to try and print a replacement instead!! That way I can re-use the whole thing... one less motor/metal/rubber/etc in the garbage!! And it did work GREAT!!! My BobSweep is back up and running... and if the wheel gets broken again, just print a new one!!! I hope other owners can enjoy this as I am right now!!! UPDATE (Nov 6th/2015):The latest model (0008) has a better fit to the bobSweep body, more centralized in the wheel hole after installed. The last one (006) works, but it was too close to the edge of the whole, slightly touching it and causing problems.

author: elsalvador325

title: Clip-on feet for play yard fence (North States Superyard)

description.text: We got a play yard recently, and although quite stable (esp. compared to other plastic products), it still moved and wobbled a bit more than we liked in an open (i.e., non-loop) configuration. So I quickly made these clip-on feet, after testing a couple of alternative designs. Fence now stays put! The clip-on foot STL is for the North States metal Superyard. I'm attaching the OpenSCAD source (which is a bit(?) messy), since it could be useful for similar configurations: if your fence has a rectangular bottom rail, with a gap between the floor and the rail, then it will be very easy to modify the dimensions (plus overall clip length, etc, if you have a printer with a bigger bed). Other rail shapes rail or fence types will likely require non-trivial modifications. Since this was a one-off design done quickly, I don't have much interest in cleaning it up for Customizer.

title: Materialize─Cosmic Typography
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Project materiallze Behind the scenes: https://youtu.be/kN6U1D8czdU
Fanpage: https://www.facebook.com/projectmaterialize/?fref=ts
Atom 3D printer:https://www.atom3dp.com
Atom 3D printer Fanpage:https://www.facebook.com/atom3D Project: Materialize With “Project: Materialize” Atom seeks to collaborate with artists and designers of all kinds to show how 3D printing can enhance self-expression for anyone. The first collaboration of Project: Materialize is with photographer Sydney Sie who, with the help of the Atom Design Team, has created striking dioramas representing different ways and forms of life. In the photos Sydney Sie uses color, light, and shape to accelerate the viewer’s imagination into parallel universes of abstract thought. Atom has supported artists and designers from day one, making a machine that is both easy to use, and delivers awesome results. Introduction - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Project Materialize is an experimental approach to presenting art. By fabricating a physical, 3D landscape the art transcends emotion and becomes a rational argument. Technology is allowing artists to break through historic restrictions as artists are no longer limited to traditional craft techniques to produce intricate physical objects. The creative goal of project materialize is to demonstrate that 3D printers are no longer a cold technology limited to engineering professionals, but can trigger the perfect combination of the material and spiritual. The Exhibition Team - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - After a number highly successful crowdfunding campaigns, Atom has built out a team of talented engineers and designers focused on the development of 3D printing and Taiwan’s specialized manufacturing sector. Atom’s team helped design the outstanding 3D models for this project, and hope to share the possibilities of this exciting new technology with the public. Using the Atom 2.0, the team invites creative people from various fields to develop their ideas and achieve their goals in photography, dance, music, science, and technology, among many others. The Artist - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Sydney Sie
https://www.facebook.com/sydneysieinfo?fref=ts Sydney Sie uses gradients of color, surreal imagery, the female body, and other graphical elements of composition, color, and layout to construct ambiguous, two dimensional worlds in her photographs. Sydney Sie’s creative approach to photography is to create a strong impression of the external form with an implied narrative buried within. She deliberately uses the inertia of the viewer’s attention to move beyond the bright colors and into the narrative story. Sydney Sie uses 3D models to “achieve the impossible,” taking a surrealistic approach to dioramic photography. After numerous discussions with the Atom Design Team, the diagrams for each of the photographs began to take form…

author: layerone

print_settings.Infill:: Not required: Better use enough perimeters

title: OpenBuild V-Slot adapter for Tontec Raspberry Pi2 case

description.text: This is an adapter to bring an OpenBuild V-Slot extrusion - like found on the Mendel Max 3 - and a Tontec aluminum Raspberry Pi2 casing together. You can find this very good casing at Amazon.de Also please take a look at my review (in German) of the casing and the use-case for this adapter at my blog www.martinmajewski.net

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.18 to 0.2 (the lower the better)

Infill:

Not required: Better use enough perimeters

Notes: I printed this adapter horizontally on the bed. Another option would be to print it upright, but then a good supporting structure is needed to stick the adapter onto the bed. Because of the 45 degree angles no supports are needed, but make sure you use plenty of perimeter loops (5 or more) to make the adapter sturdy, especially where the thin middle-part is. Print slowly and try to avoid wrapping. I haven't done so and it was some force needed to push it into the V-Slot extrusion. But this was my fault, as the adapter was designed with enough clearance and should fit nicely if printed correctly.
Wrapped corners and some debris makes the adapter harder to insert into the V-Slot extrusion, so try to print it as precisely as possible.

description.text:
Project materiallze Behind the scenes: https://youtu.be/kN6U1D8czdU
Fanpage: https://www.facebook.com/projectmaterialize/?fref=ts
Atom 3D printer:https://www.atom3dp.com
Atom 3D printer Fanpage:https://www.facebook.com/atom3D Project: Materialize With “Project: Materialize” Atom seeks to collaborate with artists and designers of all kinds to show how 3D printing can enhance self-expression for anyone. The first collaboration of Project: Materialize is with photographer Sydney Sie who, with the help of the Atom Design Team, has created striking dioramas representing different ways and forms of life. In the photos Sydney Sie uses color, light, and shape to accelerate the viewer’s imagination into parallel universes of abstract thought. Atom has supported artists and designers from day one, making a machine that is both easy to use, and delivers awesome results. Introduction - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Project Materialize is an experimental approach to presenting art. By fabricating a physical, 3D landscape the art transcends emotion and becomes a rational argument. Technology is allowing artists to break through historic restrictions as artists are no longer limited to traditional craft techniques to produce intricate physical objects. The creative goal of project materialize is to demonstrate that 3D printers are no longer a cold technology limited to engineering professionals, but can trigger the perfect combination of the material and spiritual. The Exhibition Team - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - After a number highly successful crowdfunding campaigns, Atom has built out a team of talented engineers and designers focused on the development of 3D printing and Taiwan’s specialized manufacturing sector. Atom’s team helped design the outstanding 3D models for this project, and hope to share the possibilities of this exciting new technology with the public. Using the Atom 2.0, the team invites creative people from various fields to develop their ideas and achieve their goals in photography, dance, music, science, and technology, among many others. The Artist - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Sydney Sie
https://www.facebook.com/sydneysieinfo?fref=ts Sydney Sie uses gradients of color, surreal imagery, the female body, and other graphical elements of composition, color, and layout to construct ambiguous, two dimensional worlds in her photographs. Sydney Sie’s creative approach to photography is to create a strong impression of the external form with an implied narrative buried within. She deliberately uses the inertia of the viewer’s attention to move beyond the bright colors and into the narrative story. Sydney Sie uses 3D models to “achieve the impossible,” taking a surrealistic approach to dioramic photography. After numerous discussions with the Atom Design Team, the diagrams for each of the photographs began to take form…

title: Laminate-Lamp v2.0 designed & created by Va_Le

description.text:
I was looking for a lamp (I am a lighting technican) for christmas or birthday present for grandma / dad / mother / etc - but not a simple lamp - I wanted a lamp never gets booring!
Here it is! All mothers / grandmas and other familymembers are happy to get pictures from the family / the grandchild(s) / sweet textes - Now you can gift every birthday / christmas / ... a new cover for the lamp and the lamp NEVER EVER gets booring!

This ist the second version of my "Laminate Lamp". The first version was using too much filament and takes too long to print. I wanted to create long time ago a lamp like this made from wood, but thats a lot ow work!
So I used my new awesome dremel 3D Printer to design & create this awesome lamp!

This lamp is designed for DIN A5 landscape paperformat.
  • For the Lamp-Basement you'll need:
    your 3D printer, filament (I prefer white),
    a LED-Lamp which not gets too hot (Melting the Filament) -> E14 socket
    a Lamp-socket with E14 Size for the LED Lamp
    a cable with switch (if u want) to electrizZzze the Lamp)
    • The holes in the Lamp basement is created with 29mm diameter - keep in mind to buy a fitting socket.
  • For the design you'll need:
    You only need a lamination-device, lamination sheets DIN A5, a writing program like Word and a normal boring laser- or ink-printer to print the pictures or texts you want to put around the lamp.
    • Create the lampcover you like or like to gift on word with normal portrait mode.
    Add a column so u have 2 - one left one right. Now fill the columns with whatever you want. But only fill to the half of the DIN A4 paper! Print your cration with the boring Printer to the A4-Sheet. Note you print it two times!
    Now cut the boring printed theets down to DIN A5. put them together - back to back and infill the lamination foil. Let's laminate it! Do it! Finished laminatig place the cration in landscape in front of you and cut off the top and the bottom welded parts. Now you can open it like a tube. Put the other welding parts together and fold between the two columns right in the middle to get something like a cube. There must be 4 sides. on each side your created column. The last step to enjoy the NEVER GETS BORING LAMP is to pull over the NEVER GETS BORING LAMP-COVER! Switch the light on and make someone happy!

BE CAREFUL WITH ELECTRICITY! NEVER overestimate YOU!! NEVER underestimate ELECTRICITY! If you don't know what to do with electricity lamps AND what current is or can do (put the hands behind the head lay on the floor and) call an electrican!
NEVER DO SOMETHING YOU DON'T KNOW or HOW TO DO! OTHERWISE IS CONNECTING THE WIRES AND PLAYING / BOTCHING AT YOUR OWN - YOUR OWN!!! YES! YOUR OWN!!!!!! RISK! This Lamp and it's desing is not created to make money. Please do not sell. Please use only privately. Otherwise engage me!!!

Version 2.1 of the lamp-base is already in workprocess with small fixes and changes.
I am new to 3D-Print so please forgive maybe wrong settings to print - if u can help me with better settings let me read in the comments

author: Va_Le

description.text:
Dual extruder using all E3D parts allowing you to order from one supplier.
The original extruder from Gyrobot is great, but didn't quite fit the components I had bought from E3D at the same time as getting my new Chimera dual hot end.
Specifically the E3D Hobb Goblin is about 1.5mm smaller in diameter than the MK7 so the filament was not gripped and the motor shafts were longer, so touched in the middle. I have also removed some material so that it is not in the way of the extruding grub screw.

2 x Hobb Goblin
2 x Stepper Motors
1 x Chimera or Cyclops
2 x 623 bearings
2 x levers from bulldog clips to use as springs (see original design)
There are a couple of options depending on the length of your motor shafts. If you have a MK7 gear and long motor shafts then you can use the original design and print or laser cut the spacers.

title: Unidirectional Low Wattage LED Circuit and Housing

description.text:
Disclamer: This is no way safe or a good idea to build. Be careful when messing with electricity.
I tested the circuit with an isolated variable ac power supply to test functionality and reliability. I am confident that it won't over heat or die after 24 hours of use. I used a Kill-A-Watt meter to monitor used power (3 watts). 
This is supposed to be a low watt replacement for incandescent bulb types. 
It is 100% safe for normal human usage.

• Print the lightface (I left the raft on the face to diffuse the light)and the body.
  • Position the LED's in the lightface and use some hotglue to keep them in place.
  • Build the circuit and test it for opens with a multimeter (if you test from one LED pin to the next with the correct way, the LED should light).
  • Solder a light bulb base or a plug to the rectifier.
  • Test. If it fails to light, unplug and retest connections.
  • Slide the body over the lightface and glue it in place.

comments.text: It would be FAR better here to use a switching MOSFET transistor as a current regulator.
comments.author: Cynar

comments.text: Why?  The voltage drop of these diodes is NOT going to change.  It is determined by quantum mechanics and the nature of the material.
comments.author: Cynar

comments.text: You haven't seen it without a series resistance, I've looked at those same circuits.
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text: thanks!
comments.author: Cynar

comments.text: PLEASE BE CAREFUL WITH THE ELECTRICAL DESIGN
comments.author: MiseryBot

comments.text: Miserybot's right, it needs a current limiting resistor. Without a resistor, you add the sum of the voltage drops, subtract from the source voltage, and then DIVIDE BY ZERO to get the current flow.
comments.author: MiseryBot

comments.text: That's not how forward voltage works...
comments.author: duffytoler

comments.text: Yes it is, sorry you don't understand it. Perhaps if you actually looked up a forward voltage curve it would help. Here, let me do that for you - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Diode-IV-Curve.svghttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F...
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text: That is a theoretical curve for a perfect diode, not a real curve for an actual one.
comments.author: duffytoler

comments.text: I'm an electronics engineer with close to 30 years experience, you are someone who obviously has NO experience with any of this.  Anyone want to prove it to themselves? Put an LED on an adjustable power supply with no dropping resistor, turn it up a little past the forward voltage, and watch what happens.  Current shoots up to as much as the supply can put out, the LED gets hot and burns out, and you discover "Corona688" would be a poor guy to take electronics advice from.
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text: Divide by zero?
comments.author: duffytoler

comments.text: Yes, Kirchhoff's Law says the sum of the voltage drops equals the source voltage.  In this circuit, the forward voltages on the LEDs and bridge diodes are fixed.  What remains is divided by whatever resistance there is (near zero in this case) to find the current - Ohm's Law.
comments.author: matrhint

comments.text: Thanks for breaking it all down for me. The whole idea came from the website I found searching: DIY LED light in google(http://superpositioned.com/2006/02/25/diy-led-lighting-guide/http://superpositioned.com/200... sayes everything you suggested). Once I get all my parts in I will throw it all together and test it with your suggestions on being safe by using a variable transformer, a grounding strap, goggles, and I will take my dogtags off too (I think i am the only person who puts their dogtags on their belt loops because I would never remember to take them off). I appreciate your help.
comments.author: MiseryBot

comments.text: Furthermore: if you use a current limiting resistor, your efficiency will lower accordingly. Efficiency of LEDs is not stellar anyway, especially not the small ones. The more practical approach is to use a constant current driver. More hardware, but safer and a longer lifetime.
comments.author: matrhint

comments.text: I thought that LEDs were the best at making light without making heat.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text: i think it depends on what color of light you want. White are not very efficient currently(in between incandescent and fluorescent), since you are trying to produce a wide range of wavelengths. pure colors are more efficient, since you are producing all the light at one wavelength.
comments.author: matrhint

comments.text: I think LED lights are more efficient as a package but cost more per bulb. 60 watt incandescent replacements for CFL use 15 watts and a 60 watt incandescent replacement LED used 7 watts; if a 60 watts is 806 lumens.
comments.author: Buback

comments.text: I will post some pictures when I get the parts in and put it together.

comments.text: I use 110v, but I don't think the parts would change much for 220.

comments.text: With 220 VAC all the voltages are doubled.  The voltage the capacitor and rectifiers see is doubled.

This is an experimental design of the M Prime One spool holder, an alpha version that we use to hold the filament spool on top of our 3D printers. It's still far from a final version, it needs a redesign, but at least is a working spool holder that you can build and improve. It's compatible with both wide and narrow filament spools, and although it is attached to the top of the printer it doesn't make it unstable. It fits in a 8mm M Prime One frame. You should modify the design if you want to use it with a different thickness frame. This spool holder is designed to be used with the M Prime One 3D printer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1058861).

• Cut the file "spool_holder_wide.dxf" twice
  • Print "spool_holder_wide_beam.stl"
  • Assemble the spool holder with 4 M3x20 screws and 4 M3 nuts

I was going to be a lumberjack for Halloween, but couldn't find a good axe to print, so I made one. It's fitted to be printed in a MakerBot Replicator 2X. It fits with a "Smedbergs Hicko"-shaft, bought at Jula in Sweden. But I've added a "test neck" if you want to see if it fits other shafts.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,3 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: Printed with ABS-filament.
If you're going to do some after work on it, I recommend 3 layers.

Rough grinding and glueing Glue & grind/hone Put much effort in the grind/hone. Since all the details that you don't get rid off will show when you add primer and coatings. Added primer First layer of chrome/metallic-coating Finished product fitted with the shaft Finished product fitted with the shaft

description.text:
Update: I have recorded a video roughly explaining the maestro set-up and programming. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yop9Zk2HJMU&feature=c4-overview&list=UUVFLoZlTjw1ntq-6utlJtog Update: I have finally finished the assembly instruction video. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QRSGdbrgLko&feature=c4-overview&list=UUVFLoZlTjw1ntq-6utlJtog Update: The files ending with SK should work with Skeinforge. I have not printed those but they look good. I removed the cone from the pin ends and replaced them with hemispheres. Printed ESRA Robot powered by 3 Hitec servos and a mini Maestro controller. The gears have Hitec splines printed into them. The servo action is controlled with ServoScribe software which has a free 4 channel download available at: http://www.pattonrobotics.com Videos of the robot in action can be seen here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mqnbv1dBfk4
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WuLC0RcsIkw I have bundled a kit to make getting parts easy. You can find it here: http://www.pattonrobotics.com

Parts:
3 Hitec Servos
1 Mini Maestro
1 4pk AA battery Holder
2 Animal Eyes
12 Self Tapping 4-40 screws
1 length of wire
1 Hair Scrunchy (these are from the dollar store) I had to print the gears and eyelids sort of slowly...
All the parts were screwed together with self tapping 4-40 screws.
The only semi-serious modification was the 8-32 tapping of the holes on the plate that holds the servos. The holes need to be tapped to allow the nylon screws to apply back pressure on the non-driven gears. See attached video.

What started off as a section of straight train track has turned into a large train set. To be honest this was a great project during Hurricane Irene weekend. Was also my birthday when I did this, so something fun to do on my birthday. My kids have gotten a kick out of them. The ones in the photos are straight off the printer, no cleanup needed, some tips on that below. This stuff all pretty much snaps together, so not much in the way of post printing work required. These train works great without tracks. I was excited that the body design worked as well as it did and suprised that the Makerbot did so well printing the tall axle towers. Would be fun to modify the wheels for more of a monster truck look. Maybe during the next hurricane... I drew this stuff in Sketchup and then exported to the stl file. If it is useful to anyone I happy to post the Sketchup files. The curve track was tricky to draw, for some reason it tends to warp up a bit on one end when printed. I think probably due to by build platform being sort of warped (need to replace the belt on my ABP...). Update 9/24/2011:I just replaced a large number of the stl files with new versions that are a lot cleaner, and should print a lot better. I also removed earlier versions that I didn't think were worth printing because the new versions were much better. All the files I've loaded here have been tested and should print well on a Makerbot.

There are a variety of parts here. You can print as many as you want to build quite a big set. One overall comment is that these print best when centered on the platform. In Skeinforge click move option and then center to assure they are centered. Train Track Sections and Train Car Body I print these using raftless printing configured basically how they describe on the makerbot wiki (http://wiki.makerbot.com/thingomatic-doc:raftless). The modifications I made are: 1) I changed the Object First Layer Feed Rate Infill Multiplier (ratio) to be 0.5 2) I change the Object First Layer Feed Rate Permieter Multiplier (ratio) to 0.5 3) I changed the Object First Layer Flow Rate Multiplier (ratio) to 0.9 4) I disabled the Outline feature and generally delete the lines of gCode that do the warm up extrusion. These changes make the first layer go down slower and a little wider/thicker so that it adheres to the platform very well. I was noticing that the outline and warm-up extrusion generally left buggers or lines of plastic that then caused the early layers to peal off. The changes above fixed that. Update 9/2/2011: I just uploaded a 1/2 length straight track section. You'll need this if you have any 45 degree runs. I'll try to post a photo of this at some point. Update 9/10/2011: You can mirror the curved track around X axis to curve the other way. Update 9/24/2011: Car body is the version with a long hitch so it works well with both types of wheels. Curved track is a new stl file that actually prints like the drawing. Train Wheels I print these using a raft (believe me I've tried raftless a lot for these and it just ends in frustration). I found that the standard raft configuration has a gap between the raft lines which I found allowed the axle to flex too much in the X direction as it got tall. To remedy this I changed the Base infill density to .65 in skeinforge. This makes the raft lines closer together so that they actually touch and form a raft that is more solid in both the X and Y directions. I do also get rid of the interface layer, by setting the interface layers to 0 in the raft config in skeinforge. Once the wheels are printed I trimmed around the edge with scissors, leaving the raft attached (it makes a nice smooth outside, so rather than fight it, join it). You can then insert the axle in the wheel with the hole, it should fit snug and require a little pressure to fully seat it. Update 9/24/2011: There are 2 wheel versions, one that is small (labeld small) and one that is large. The larger wheels have a larger outside flange that does help the train stay on the tracks better, the inside wheel is still the same diameter so you can run both versions on the track in the same train just fine. I still find that the train doesn't stay on the track that well, my kids don't seem to care, 99% of the fun seems to be building and clipping stuff together, the actual train running is minimal... These trains have the flange reversed from a normal train (which has the flange on the inside of the wheel), would be tough to print this configuraiton with the axle attached. I've also made both wheels up here now stronger, by making the axle go all the way through the wheel, so that when it prints is it not just fused to the surface of the top layer of the wheel, but goes all the way through. "Tops" There are 4 different style car tops. I printed them all with the same raft configuration that the Train Wheels are printed with. They snap into place on top of the Train Body (there are two holes in the body and 2 pins on the top part). Mine fit firmly enough that again no glue was needed, but if you want to make them rugged it wouldn't hurt. Update 9/5/2011: I just posted 2 new cars a grain car and a coal car. See new photo for examples. Update 9/10/2011: I just uploaded 3 new car tops: A Passenger Car; A "Cage" Car; A Tender Car (hold coal and water for the engine). The Tender car is the most finiky of the car tops I've made when it comes to printing. I think its all the movment when it gets tall that tends to throw it off (snaps the raft free of the ABP), you might want to set the raft a big bigger to print this. I set my Raft Additional Margin over Length(%) to 1.3 and my Raft Margin (mm) to 6.0, which seemed to help. Update 9/24/2011: All car tops still are the same, however I've cleaned up the STL files (removed reversed faces, holes, etc... at least NetFabb doesn't complain). They don't really print any differently for me, but figured while I was cleaning things up I'd fix these too.

I've also found you need to be really precise when using follow-me tool to create curves or you can end up with small holes.

title: Accessory band with Maglite holder- Ruger® 10/22

description.text:
This is a modification to the accessory band for the Ruger® 10/22 Collector Series.
Similar to my last release, but this one includes an integrated Maglite holder.
NOTE:This part was designed around the MAGLITE LED XL50 FLASHLIGHT. It is a little pricey but bright as the surface of the sun. Get it at Amazon.com

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Fine as possible

Infill:

as dense as possible

To properly locate the band, remove the front strap mount from the rifle. There is a peg in the lower half of the band that will fit in the hole that is left.
Each part has a small bump which identifies the front face of the band. This necessary due to the taper in the front of the rifle.
Parts hold nicely with four 1 1/2" #6-32 pan head screws and nuts.

comments.text:
I'm very sorry to hear that you are having trouble with the files.
I have never used Slic3r so I can't offer assistance with that software.
The files have been up for over two years now with hundreds of downloads and you are the first to let me know that you've had problems with it. I did create them using 3ds Max in inch measurements. The STL check feature in Max can sometimes be a little wiggy. but I don't believe they were any issues with that particular set of files .
Maybe perhaps it's possible that there was a corruption in the downloaded file. I would recommend deleting the file and trying to re-download it and see if that helps. unfortunately, beyond that there isn't much I think I can do to help you. Other than wishing you the best of luck.
If you are new to the slic3r software maybe you could find someone else who has it and see if they can get ithe file to load correctly.

title: TinyOLED V1.2/V1.3 for RAMPS : OLED,  TF Card, Encoder, Connector, Bluetooth, Wifi

description.text:
TinyOLED Module 128x64 for RAMPS (using D20, D21 on RAMPS 1.4) V1.2 : for OLED with GND, VCC, SCL, SDA
V1.3 : for OLED with VCC, GND, SCL, SDA • 128x64 pixel 1.3" I2C OLED / 0.96" I2C OLED (Detachable)
• TinyOLED V1.2 Connector Board (Custom Design : 45mm x 37mm)
• TF Card Module (Offline Printing, Detachable)
• Rotary Encoder (User Control)
• BlueTooth HC-05 Module (Wireless Connection - short range, Detachable)
• ESP8266-01 WIFI Module (Wifi Connection - long range, Deachable) Printing Option
  • USB (COM Port) + TF Card + Bluetooth (COM Port)
  • USB (COM Port) + TF Card + WIFI (COM Port)
  • WIFI (TCP/IP) + TF Card + Bluetooth (COM Port)
    • •Change Bitmap to OLED with LCD Bitmap converter
    http://digole.com/tools/PicturetoC_Hex_converter.php http://www.HKMakers.hk https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C3Gf1nd3yl0 P.S. MKS Mini / Base V1.0 ~ V1.4 , Please make sure your board have D20, D21 or i2c pin
Bluetooth HC-05 Setting : Setup using Arduino Uno

9 -> State
10 -> TX
11 -> RX
GND -> GND
5V -> 5V
  • Load BT.ino from arduino.cc
  • Press Button on HC-05 and Power on Arduino.UNO and HC-05

  • Open Serial Monitor from arduino IDE
    AT+VERSION? // Show version
    AT+ORGL // Restore default status
    AT+UART? // Show UART status
    AT+UART:115200,0,0 // Set Bluetooth Speed
    AT+NAME:"TinyOLED" // Set Bluetooth Name
    AT+CMODE=0 // Set Mode
    AT+ROLE=0 // Set Slave Mode

  • Pair Bluetooth TinyOLED / 1234 from PC, SmartPhone or Tablet
  • Connect using 11520 from Repetier-Host with the first COM Port from BT
  • Finished with showing temperature of hotend to room temperature

ESP8266-01 WIFI Setting
  • Insert ESP8266 onto USB ESP8266 Flasher
  • Short GPIO0 to GND
  • Insert into PC

  • download NodeMCU Flasher
    https://github.com/nodemcu/nodemcu-flasher

  • download NodeMCU firmware
    https://github.com/nodemcu/nodemcu-firmware

  • Load NodeMCU firmware into ESP8266 using NodeMCU Flasher

  • Download ESplorer - Integrated Development Environment (IDE) for ESP8266 developers
    https://github.com/4refr0nt/ESPlorer

  • Download init.lua from here and change the following
    cfg.ssid= "Wifi SSID" // Your router wifi SSID
    cfg.pwd="WIFI Password" // Your router wifi password

    cfg.ip="ESP8266 IP Address" // 192.168.0.100
    cfg.netmask="Subnet Mask" // 255.255.255.0
    cfg.gateway="Gateway IP Address" // 192.168.0.1
    port = 9876 // Port to connect

  • Upload Init.lua onto ESP8266 using ESPlorer
    • Final : Setup Repetier-Host to connect using IP Address
    192.168.0.100:9876
    http://creatorbot.com/projects/electronics/add-esp8266-wifi-to-your-3d-printer Marlin Setting enable define from configuration.h // Tiny SSD1306 OLED I2C 128x64 FULL GRAPHICS CONTROLLER

description.text:
This is a fluidic amplifier from this patent. It should have a pretty nice frequency response as it is intended to be used a part of a sound amplifier circuit for a gramophone. If you make several other amplifiers according to the sizes in the patent and wire them up according to the patent, you sould be able to make a completely fluidic acoustic amplifier. Specifications derived from patent:
Nozzle size is 0.02" x 0.016" and operating supply pressure is 0.5 PSI. NOTE: this thing is tiny!

This is a derivative of www.thingiverse.com/thing:7544 It is two piece device allows you to get a firm hold on any type of textile without puncturing them. The first part of the device, which we will call the lock (get here: www.thingiverse.com/thing:7544), fits closely into the base, which we will call the star because of the original resemblance to a ninja throwing star. In this derivative the 4 prong star is simplified into two prongs to cut down on polymer use and print time. This device has numerous useful applications around the home no matter where you live. All of the original applications will still work:
  • Stretcher -? 6 fasteners, a blanket and 2 poles
  • Hammock - 2 fasteners and a blanket
  • Emergency Tent -? 4 fasteners and a plastic sheet or tarp
  • Greenhouse or row guard - Use a number of fasteners and clear plastic to create a greenhouse
  • Food transport - Use some form of fabric and 4 fasteners to make flexible box for carrying things like vegetables
  • Improved Tarps:
    • You can use a fastener to fix a grommet that has popped out of a normal tarp.
    • You can also use a number of fasteners to join multiple tarps together into a bigger tarp
    • You can create a custom waterproof cover
    • You can use the fasteners to hold the tarp in a custom way for another function -? such as rain water collection or roof leak or boat protector.
      The project webpage is here

To Make:
The STL files for printing both the star and the lock are available here and can be printed out of various materials on an open source rapid prototyper like the RepRap. To Use:
  • Wrap the lock in the fabric with its flat side touching the fabric.
  • Push the lock and the fabric through the hole in the star.
  • Turn the lock piece 90 degrees and pull into place (as shown assembled in Figure 1).
  • To take the fastener off just follow steps 1 through 3 in reverse.
    • Both the lock and the star have multiple holes that can be used either with tie lines or nails depending on your application. Suggestions for improvement always welcome.

This is a derivative of Skimbal's CD-Rom motor pump, thingiverse.com/thing:4881, but with screw mounting and a 6mm circular outlet. Youtube video of it here: http://youtu.be/us2KlyBPEaU I may design a V2 sometime, possibly without screws and without need for any support material.

1) Print out parts. I paused the print of the housing partway through to brush some oil on the support material around the shaft. That in theory makes it easier to remove later.  
2) Remove support material from the pump housing where the shaft will go. This allows the motor to rest flat against the plastic.  
3) Screw on the motor using two small screws. If the motor shaft does not spin freely then you may have to drill it out a little.  
4)Press the impeller as far as possible onto the motor shaft without it rubbing.  
5) Spin up the motor and sand down the impeller blades until they are just below the top of the pump housing.  
6) Using a hot glue gun, glue on the lid and make sure it is completely sealed around the edges. I had to raise the lid up slightly since I was lazy sanding down the impeller.  
7) Power it up and submerge in water. On my version a little bit of water did start seeping out the motor itself.  
You can also use the pump as a generator using either an air compressor or vacuum cleaner. don't run it for too long otherwise you will wear out the motor bearings or brushes.

This is a fully parametric measuring scoop/cup. Give the desired volume, desired radius, shell thickness, and handle size, and it will generate a fully printable measuring scoop. Originally a request from the wife for a new coffee scoop. The bottom is conical to help printing. You can adjust the angle of the cone by altering the ratio of volume in the cylinder section to the volume of the cone. Found some scrap filament to print and have uploaded fixes to ensure it is printable. Changelog:
  • prints out the cone angle in openscad when you build so you can quickly tell if it will work with your equipment
  • added a parameter to allow you to change the handle support structure size.
  • uploaded a newer one oz scoop that should be printable (waiting on a print now)
    • v2:
  • smoother cylinder (takes a bit longer to skein, though)
  • add optional mickey mouse ears for raftless
  • add optional round exterior, but keep conical interior for printability
  • fix stupid maths errors that cause the volume to be off by 1/2. :(
    • Print tests of v1 and v2 turned out excellent!

A one oz coffee scoop is attached as an example.
To generate your own in scad look in the one-oz-coffee-scoop.scad as an example.
Print with 0 extra shells or you may hit the skeinforge bug. I print with 0.265 layers, 100% infill on my Thing-O-Matic.

comments.text: So the one oz measuring scoop doesnt print well with the default parameters. It starts stringing when it gets to the cone part, as it's a bit too steep. I'll see about a fixed version.

description.text:
yaobls (Yet Another Open Bench Logic Sniffer) Case This is a case for the OBLS (Open Bench Logic Sniffer) design.
< http://dangerousprototypes.com/docs/Open_Bench_Logic_Sniffer > The purpose of this case is to reduce the chance of ESD damage
to the OBLS circuitry during ordinary use and handling.
In addition, I wanted to gain some experience with the tool chain
that I intend to use to fabricate case prototypes for another project.

This yaobls case was fabricated in SLS nylon at Shapeways.
< http://www.shapeways.com/model/307051/ > Consult the "yaobls case" thread on the Dangerous Prototypes OBLS forum.
< http://dangerousprototypes.com/forum/viewforum.php?f=23 > The case design was created using Autodesk Inventor Professional 2011. The top window was fabricated in 1/16" clear acrylic using a laser cutter.
The top window design was created using CorelDRAW X5. dsm

Using Shapeways allowed a surface with fine details.
Using Shapeways allowed an overhang at the board insertion end of the case without scaffolding.

description.text: I recently designed a bottle opener ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11025) in OpenSCAD, and I wanted to sexify it with a Makerbot M. Searching thingiverse I was unable to find native OpenSCAD code that did what I wanted. I either needed to import an STL, extrude a dxf, or install a font. ...so I made a MakerbotM module. Rather than just bury it in the Bottle Opener's .scad file, I've broken it out here for others to enjoy. UPDATED: I encorporated tbuser's changes (more faces on the cylinder) as well as extended the middle leg up into the body of the M, removing some occasional weirdness that was happening during differences.

the module accepts two parameters:
height: how tall you want the M to be.
thickness: how thick you want the M to be. when positioning, the origin of the part is the center.

Engine Mount Designed to use a paper clip on the bottom to hold engine.
Decided on the engine type i wanted to use and made the rocket to fit the engine.  I also tried to make it as light as possible but still strong.

Objective Students will learn how to design a simple model rocket. They will also gain a better understanding of the design cycle, through use of it. Audiences Middle school and up in drafting, engineering, and physics classes. Preparation Students should have a better understanding of how model rockets work.
Students should have access to 3d modeling software and basic knowledge of the software.
Students should know the engine they are using for their rockets.
Students should also have access to a 3d printer(s).
Classroom needs computers for every student/group with the 3d modeling software.
Classroom need a model rocket launcher, rockets, and an area to launch. Steps
  • Explain project to students
  • Allow students/groups to determine what their designs will need to work.
  • Start designing and 3d modeling
  • Print finished works
  • Test Rockets
  • Gain feedback and redesign
  • Retest Rockets
  • repeat 6, and 7 as many times as you wish.
  • (Optional) have students create and give a presentation on the (design cycle, use of physics concept, etc.) and how they used it.
    • Results Students should have designed and texted one or multiple rockets, and have gained a better knowledge of model rockery and the concept betting taught.

If, like me, you wanted to use bigger batteries on your Discovery Endurance build then you probably found that mounting them on the top plate was difficult at best, and the bolt heads would protrude into the battery - not ideal. These "backpacks" allow you mount bigger batteries on top of your Disco. They provide a flat surface so your batteries aren't damaged, and allow you to use straps to secure them.
The Standard and Pro Discovery have slightly different bolt hole / solder pin layouts, hence the widened front holes so that the plates can fit on either one. Using an 8000mAh battery on my build I got a 38 minute maximum flight time. You could push that slightly higher with a 10000mAh :) I'm using Hobbywing X-rotor ESCs, Multistar 390kv motors, 15x5 CF props and a Pixhawk. The OF/LIDAR plate is designed for the PX4FLOW optical flow sensor and the PulsedLight LIDAR Lite v1 rangefinder (though I believe the v2 has the same dimensions). UPDATED 30/01/16 - rolled the separate Discovery / Discovery Pro plates into single universal plates.

You'll want to drill out all the holes to 3mm.
Some of the top plate screws sit underneath the backpack; for these screws I used the standard Disco/DJI M3 low-profile hex screws which fit under nicely.
I used M3 cap head screws (as provided with the AerialMob arms) to secure the backpacks. They sit perfectly flush with the top of the plate when tightened down.

description.text:
Refill bottles rarely fit on their counterparts, you have to hold them by hand all the time. Creamy fluids like laundry detergents can take a long time, a boring process.   
Enter the customizable bottle adapter. With its integrated funnel, nothing drips along the adapter and outside the bottle, and everything is kept clean.

Check the resulting STL, with reasonable parameters there should be no need for support structures. The inset parameter must be just large enough to leave room for the wall of the lower bottle. Adjust with the heights of the cones (inner and outer) to minimze overhang angle.

description.text: I wanted a sturdy keyring than could hold securely small things, electronical components, screws, nuts,screwer bits, liitle tools, etc. (Don't put inside candies or pills unless you print it in P.E.T. plastic!!) I don't ever know what kind of stuff I will need, so I thought about it and this is the result. A cute ellipsoidal ('Beaned') keychain hard to open (pressure is configurable as you tighten the spring). You just need a M3x30 screw, a small spring, a M3 nyloc nut (recommended) and some glue. Insert the nyloc nut in the top part, Insert the M3 screw into the spring and screw it into the nut from the bottom part. Depending of the spring size you may have to use a shorter M3 screw or cut it down. Do your proof till you feel the thingie can be opened/closed comfortably, then use some glue to fix the parts supplied to hide the holes and you are done!! The bottom hole filling part should be trimmed according to your setup. Easy and proffesional. Don't let your friends see it or you'll have to make some for them. You can figure out why I called it 'BeanBox'. Its not big but also no tiny. Its just the size I needed, it can hold 25 cm3. and works perfect for me. You have to file it a bit to get a perfect fit. Also nice results are got when sanding its surface. As you wear this thing in your pockets or necklace I don't recommend to paint it unless after painting you apply several varnish layers. Not a toy, it is designed sturdy to last. Remember at print time that the top part requires support !! Hint: If you scale it up by a factor of 1.34. Then you have a larger version and you can use M4 screw/nut and a larger spring. Anyway the one showed in the pics is the normal M3 version. If you want a bigger one, you can try using a 1.67 scale factor and M5 screw/nut. If this is still not enough for you... then I challenge you to build the beast, scale it to 2.67 and use M8 screw/nuts (this should be insane insane insane hahaha, maybe you could even carry inside your lunch!!) As FreeCAD sources are included you can customize it to your will. Place a 'remix' with pics if you have a nice idea, I'll be happy to see it. Hint: I printed mine in phosphorescent ABS to find it easily turning off lights, and also to a better "after print" processing. I am thinking about printing it on Ninjaflex but after print work would be crazy... Hint: If you want it waterproof, just print it with any flexible filament. Happy BeanBoxing !!! UPDATE (08-NOV-2015): Added a top part modified to use the beanbox as a necklace in a more convenient way. Added a Open Hardware logo bottom version. UPDATE (09-NOV-2015): Increased the size of the top into bottom inserting zone to allow a better seal for the waterproof flexible filament print. Unfortunately this forces a bit more sanding in non-flex versions. Anyhow a bit of sanding is required for a perfect fit in those versions. For the waterproof one just use stainless steel screw and spring.
